Award.AwardTitle: NSF East Asia and Pacific Summer Institute for FY 2012 in Japan
Award.AbstractNarration:
This action funds Colleen Carlston of Cold Spring Harbor Laboratory to conduct a research project, entitled "Regulatory changes in flatworm gene expression during learning," during the summer of 2012 at Kyoto University. The host scientist is Dr. Kiyokazu Agata.

The Intellectual Merit of the research project is the study of habituation to light in the model organim, Planaria, a flat worm. Using genetic tools, the pathway that leads to habituation to light is being investigated in both nervous and non-nervous tissues to determine how protein synthesis may play a role in this learning.

Broader Impacts of an EAPSI fellowship include providing the Fellow a first-hand research experience outside the U.S.; an introduction to the science, science policy, and scientific infrastructure of the respective location; and an orientation to the society, culture and language. These activities meet the NSF goal to educate for international collaborations early in the career of its scientists, engineers, and educators, thus ensuring a globally aware U.S. scientific workforce.

Science as it is taught in the classroom seems to progress linearly, with one discovery logically leading to the next. However, those involved in the day-to-day enterprise quickly learn that at the scientific frontier consensus is rare, and a once lauded idea can turn laughable even without an adequate hypothesis to supplant the one that has been discarded. Put another way, there are many experimental dead-ends, and scientists often avoid topics once the enthusiasm of their peers has cooled.

 

The study of memory and learning in planaria (a highly regenerative flatworm that can regrow all tissues including the brain) has a checkered history. In the mid-fifties, the psychology professor James McConnell began studying Pavlovian training in planaria by pairing a light stimulus with an electrical shock. This conditioned the flatworms to constrict (a normal response to electrical shocks) in response to light alone. Interestingly, the memory of this conditioning appeared to be retained in worms that regenerated from either the head or the tail after the original worm was cut in half. This led McConnell to hypothesize about mechanisms for distributed, non-neuronal memory (i.e., memory that’s not stored just in the head/brain). In his most famous set of experiments, McConnell ground up trained flatworms and fed them to naïve (untrained) flatworms, and demonstrated memory transfer through cannibalism. Then by isolating ribonucleic acid (RNA) from trained worms and injecting it into naïve worms, McConnell also seemed to improve their performance. He came to believe RNA was the substrate of memory and coined the term memory RNA. However, others had trouble replicating these experiments, and as the neuroscience field developed the concept of memory RNAs appeared increasingly preposterous.

 

This was still 30 years before the field of RNA biology really took off. At this point RNA seemed a rather dull molecule – the workhorse that dutifully conveyed genetic information from DNA to make protein. However, in the last decade or so, the essential role of noncoding RNAs (i.e. RNAs that do not encode proteins) in gene regulation has become apparent.  In fact, there is now practically an alphabet soup of such RNAs (miRNA, piRNA, siRNA, lncRNA, snoRNA, etc.). My PhD mentor, Dr. Chris Hammell, studies one such class of non-coding RNAs, microRNAs (miRNAs), in development, and in light of the advances made in this burgeoning area, I wondered if McConnell’s abandoned work was worth reexamining.

 

Young scientists, who did not experience the fallout from the original controversy, may be tempted to apply modern techniques to once and for all settle the question. I was cautioned to tread carefully by Dr. Agata, a world expert on planaria, when we discussed this project. The final impetus to investigate this question came when I discovered that the Agata lab had cloned an RNA helicase (a molecule that unwinds RNA) in planaria and demonstrated that it was highly expressed in both stem cells and the brain. I had been working on the same helicase in the Hammell lab, and knew that it was regulating the activity of miRNAs. By lowering the level of this helicase in planaria (using a technique known as RNAi knockdown), we could now observe whether this would affect memory formation.

 

As it turned out, genes that are strongly expressed in both stem cells and the brain are more common than one might expect. I successfully knocked down the RNA helicase and a few other genes that also fell into this category, and none of them had obvious effects on movement or light avoidance.  Replicating McConnell’s memory experiments proved more difficult.
